Comments_List: I learned so much about the human brain, its anatomy and function. It was also a great introduction to the field of neuroscience as a whole.

Taking it in conjunction with Intro Psych, I discovered how much overlap there is between these fields and how psych and neuroscience play off one another in a fascinating way. 

We also definitely covered A LOT of information about the brain.

Thorough understanding of basic principles of neuroscience, mostly with respect to structural function and other related topics. Also a great overview of human behavior from a neuroscience perspective
Learned about how a variety of sensory and cognitive processes are organized in the brain.
In depth look into the human brain.

Learned about the brain and how it functions (from cellular level to systems level), how we study it (methods), how different parts give rise to various functions (movement, perception, decision-making), and how we are affected when these parts are damaged (aphasia, agnosia, etc.)
You learn so much about the brain, its parts, its functions, etc.
I gained a thorough understanding of the brain and how it functions.
I learned a lot about specific mechanics behind how the human brain works in an accessible way.
A lot about the human brain. How to cram?

I developed a familiarity with the human brain and major methods and findings of neuroscientific research from the earlier days of its study up into contemporary disputes. I learned how the brain functioned on a microscopic level and learned how to enter more complex/uncertain conversations about attention, social neuroscience, etc. And, as someone who's never taken a college-level science course before, I now feel confident that I can set up and evaluate scientific experiments and contextualize knowledge in a field that is rapidly evolving.
This class really laid the foundation for any other neuroscience class I will take.
I obtained a lot of insight about the intricacies about the human brain, as the class name suggests.
Basic concepts of neuroscience, especially that which is related to psychology.
I learned the anatomy and physiology of the human brain in very great detail.
I learned a lot of good facts about the brain.

This was a thorough introduction to anatomy, methods, and research in neuroscience. The course became more and more interesting, and I loved learning about the scientific processes behind human systems like memory, emotion, stress, and sleep.

Somatosensory system (touch, proprioception), vision, audition, stress, emotion, motor control, morality, theory of mind, sleep, empathy, pain, different agnosias, attention, executive functions, memory, neuroscience techniques (fMRI, TMS, ERPs, PET, MRI), brain anatomy
everything about the brain. everything.
general knowledge of the brain anatomy and function, methods used to investigate brain activity, and interesting case studies
This course taught me an great deal about the human brain and was a very effective combination of the psychology and the neuroscience behind it.
This class is great for anyone who wants a rigorous introduction to basic neuroscience and neurobiology.
I learned a lot of new materials that I had never been exposed to before.
I learned a lot about the human brain but there was also way too much information to learn in a semester that I probably don't know most of it. :(
We learned seemingly EVERYTHING there is to know about the brain. There was so much information in every lecture but it was fascinating.
Basic knowledge of neuroscience, brain parts, symptoms, and applications.
I learned about the human brain's structures, functions, and every thing else that encompasses the brain's activities in the body, as well as historical thoughts about the brain.
A lot more knowledge about the brain.

Great overview of structure and function of the brain and Professor McCarthy did a great job teaching this very complicated material. I would say knowledge gained in this class is essential for all psych majors.
Learn about the physiology of the Human Brain
I learned the rudiments of neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, as well as how the brain and behavior are interrelated.
This course offered an overview of different brain regions and their function as understood today, as well as a brief overview of the cells and processes that make up these regions.
Gained general knowledge about different areas in neuroscience research

This course taught me about the scientific perspective of studying the brain, including anatomy, and using several diseases/disorders as case studies to match brain region with general brain function.
I learned A LOT about the brain.

The volume of information provided in this class can be intense and sometimes overwhelming, but this class is worth it. It is an in-depth introduction to neuroanatomy, human behavior and decision-making, brain disorders, and so many more fields of neuroscience that were once obscure to me. Highly recommend!
You get a great overview of the brain.
I learned an impressive amount of material about the brain!!
The course taught me how to approach the study of neuroscience and how the brain works (in general terms)

There was a lot of information taught in this class, giving me a strong overall grasp of the brain and its functions. I learned the physical components of the brain, their specific functions and responsibilities, how lesions can impact these functions, and new technical jargon to describe the brain.

I learned so much information about the human brain! This was by far the most interesting class I took this semester. I didn't understand how complex and wonderful the brain really was until I took this course.
I learned a lot about the human brain and the different diseases and ways it changes. I learned how it works differently and how intertwined yet separate every part of the brain is.

This is an extremely broad, in depth and intensive course in Neuroscience. It fascinates you with the numerous deficits associated with various regions of the brain and allows you to get a general overview of the physiology and anatomy (these sections of the course are overwhelming and you'll finish with a decent idea of everything, likely).
This course provided a broad overview of structure-function relationships in the brain as well as navigational vocabulary and plenty of case study examples.
I obtained knowledge about the functions of different regions of the brain. We learned about the connections of the different senses in the brain, social neuroscience, and many more.
This was one of my favorite classes at Yale! I learned a lot about the brain and would and it's functions in more detail than I thought.

I learned everything about the human brain I've been wanting to learn for ages! This course focused on learning about the brain through the lens of function, meaning it wasn't just learning about anatomy. I've been able to apply some of the knowledge from this class into my daily life even!
So much!
I got an in-depth overview of neuroscience, from the cellular to the behavioral level.
You learn all about how the human brain works, from how each individual synapse fires to the macro-structure.
Study skills, a detailed overview of the form and function of the human brain.
SO MUCH about the human brain!
I learned a lot about specific studies and experiments looking at the influence of lesions in various regions of the brain.
I learned about the human brain, and the cognitive functions associated with different areas.
A walkthrough overview of cognitive neuroscience with very interesting phenomena including insights about brain function from split-brain patients.
I learned more about how the Human Brain operates.

I learned almost everything about the brain, from how neuronal communication occurs to different "systems" in the brain (visual system, motor system, sensory system, etc.) to "big-picture" concepts (stress, sleep, emotion, etc.)
I learned a lot about the human brain.
My knowledge of the subject was vastly increased and in a more diverse way than I thought possible before the course.

I learned about the anatomy and functions of the human brain, historical views on brain structure and function, and methods of studying the brain in neuroscience. The topics that were covered also led me to think about about the intersection of neuroscience and psychology, economics and sociology.

I really like how lectures were recorded, it was really helpful in reviewing for the final. I also think that the quizzes were a good way to keep up with the material. A suggestion I would make is to provide more insight in regard to the final and what to study. I felt that there was so much covered in class, that something like an outline of topics to prepare for would have provided more direction.  I also think this class could benefit from a section, where we could review the information learned in lecture in a smaller setting.

The weekly quiz structure, while an attempt to fix the Midterm issue of previous years, was quite annoying. Instead of a regular problem set, this was an open note, online quiz, which would have been fine except that you need to block out a 3 hour period of time because once you start the quiz, there's no way to pause it. 
I didn't mind the weekly "Pset," but the stressful time constraints of finding that weekly 3 hour chunk was quite difficult. 

The final's structure and questions didn't reflect what Professor McCarthy recommended the class study in preparation for it. The questions were obscure, poorly worded, and placed a large emphasis on hyper-specific neural regions, which was not something we were told to focus on in our studying.

Strengths in the clarity of lectures and quantity of information you can learn in just a semester. I took this for the Sc credit as a humanities major, and was impressed by how engaging the lectures were throughout the semester. Because there are just quizzes (aka 3 hours of work once a week), the course never felt like a burden, but  it definitely sustained my attention. Professor McCarthy is a pro at the material and you can tell that he keeps the class updated with new research. The amount of reference info in the notes and textbook were perfect. For weaknesses, this class could probably have an optional section available. Quiz comments were often unclear and unhelpful, so seeing an answer key or rubric would have been nice. Not having a practice exam available during reading period was annoying, since it was so unclear how the open-book quizzes would translate into exam questions.

strengths: lots of resources/ information available

weakness: quizzes, although nice during the semester, didn't create incentive to commit material to memory

Class covered a lot of material on many different topics! A very good introductory course to the brain and how it works. Goes over a different topic each lecture, and spends two lectures on the more important topics, allowing for a more detailed understanding.

strengths: the material is very interesting and engaging if you are interested in the human brain and Prof. Mccarthy is a good lecturer
Weaknesses: The sheer volume of information you need to know for the cumulative final is an incredible amount. I think having midterms would be better than weekly open book quizzes. I also think this class would really benefit from having sections. Another weakness this semester was that the feedback on these weekly quizzes was not very useful.

I appreciated the switch in format from the midterms+final to weekly quizzes+final. I think having the weekly quiz was really helpful in reinforcing/learning what we had just covered in lecture. The final was just really nitpick-y and required a ridiculous amount of attention to detail, way more than I think is necessarily to show a good grasp on the material.

Strength: Teaching us the fundamentals of the brain

Weakness: In terms of grading, the weekly quizzes did very little for my learning. I would prefer a midterm and a final, as the midterm would give an indication as to how the final would look. Because we did not have a midterm, the final looked extremely foreign to me and negatively impacted my grade.

This course was super interesting and I appreciated all the support- taped lectures, online notes, weekly review sessions etc.  The material was engaging and fun to learn.  I thought a more complete rundown of each main brain part, its location and its function would have been helpful rather than just learning different things about the hippocampus in different units.  I thought the quizzes were a great way of reviewing the material and were less stressful than midterms.  However, they were still hard and I definitely did not get perfect scores.

I hope Professor McCarthy will take this criticism into consideration as he designs the course for further iterations. The online quizzes had a good meaning--allowing for one to engage with the material in a low stress way that could be tested and assessed. A flaw was that the grading wasn't transparent and the answer keys unreleased because of some weird personal philosophy of the professor. Whatever, Fine.The final was beyond cruel.

I really appreciated Professor McCarthy's clarity and the degree to which he made the course's resources accessible. This course used technology well; I definitely think one of the course's strengths was how he made all of the lecture slides, notes (with links to other interesting/relevant articles) and the lecture videos themselves available online. I definitely referenced them a lot when doing the weekly quizzes and preparing for the exam, and I appreciated being able to review material at my own pace. Piazza also was a great asset for clearing up confusion and expressing curiosity; Professor McCarthy would review the literature on whatever topic a student expressed interest in, which was awesome.

Definitely one of the course's biggest strengths was its primary use of case studies, consistent with how a great deal of neuroscientific knowledge comes from lesion studies. You couldn't replicate this class by just reading the textbook, especially because the field is changing so quickly-- and Professor McCarthy gave us the tools to evaluate knowledge as contextual rather than absolute.

I also liked the weekly quizzes, which made up 70% of our grade. They focus the class on consistent learning rather than one high-stakes performance assessment. And because they were open-note, if you committed to a few draining hours every week to be super thorough, you could feel confident in a decent end grade. Often during them I felt skeptical that I was really learning, as I basically reformulated the lecture notes, but when rereading the quiz questions cold to prepare for the final, I surprised myself with how much I had internalized and remembered.

As for weaknesses, there wasn't much of a culture of asking questions in class. Though a great learning experience, it was also definitely an anonymous one; I didn't have to actually interact with other students, the teaching fellows, or the professor to do well in the course, which some might think is a weakness. Perhaps the role of the teaching fellows could be made more clear.

This class was relatively low-stress until reading week (when it became a huge commitment). Throughout the semester, open-notes quizzes gave a general idea of the way we would be evaluated. In addition, class engagement was entirely up to you, since Prof. McCarthy posts lecture slides, talking points, and videos. I also personally find Prof. McCarthy engaging and the material fascinating. The class's weakness was the final -- while there were review sessions, there was no indication of what might be on the test and rather the general instruction to "know everything." Considering the volume of information covered, this was nearly impossible and induced a lot of stress and barred me from studying for some of my other exams until the last minute.

In the short-term, the quizzes were a strength because one got to learn the material without the stress associated with preparing for a midterm. Long-term, however, the quizzes were a huge weakness. Although Professor McCarthy tried to alleviate anxiety by giving us quizzes, the quizzes were of no help when taking the final exam, as most of the questions asked on the final were nothing like quiz questions. The quizzes were also graded pretty harshly, so that, in itself, was discouraging in the hopes to perform well in the course. In addition, we were essentially left in the dark about the overall format and of the final, which was also discouraging and could have been circumvented if we were given midterms. Thus, although Professor McCarthy had good intentions in switching to quizzes, they, in my opinion, were not an effective change to the format of the course.
Great introductory course, difficult because of how broad the course was. IT covered a very wide range of topics in great detail. But taught well nonetheless

Having the weekly quizzes was useful, but it also made the final exam content more of a mystery because I didn't know what would be emphasized or what the format or style of questions would be going into the final exam.

The professor was great. He knew his material, he was organized, he was dependable, and he cared about his students.

There was just too much stuff on each lecture. it was difficult to gauge what needed to be known for the Final exam based on the quizzes.

So. Much. Material. And there was no way to tell how in-depth your knowledge was going to be tested on the final, which ended up being hell.
McCarthy is a great lecturer though and I always enjoyed attending.
The TFs were often way too picky and kind of condescending in their grading, however, which was discouraging.

This course is very well organized. Our textbook is helpful, and Prof McCarthy posted lecture videos, lecture slides, and thorough written notes. All the information is available to us! 
Weekly open-book quizzes kept me on top of the information, but ultimately, I didn't really memorize anything until the week before the final exam... which was extremely challenging!

One strength of this class was that the lecture recordings, notes, and slides were all posted online. Since the class was at 1pm (right after lunch!!) I was always far too sleepy to pay attention in class. However, because the lecture recordings were posted online, I could watch them on my own time. One weakness of this class was that the online, take-home quizzes made it easy to not stay completely on top of things before the final, so the cumulative final was crazy stressful. I actually think I would have preferred two midterms, and a final (cumulative or not).

i liked the weekly quizzes. I would have hated having 2 midterms and a final. However, there is just soooooo much information. Possibly in addition to these quizzes, have one midterm and then one final non cumulative. That way, students don't die when studying for this.
The course was very interesting but i feel like there was a lot of information and the class could have been challenging if i did not have prior neuroscience information.

I think that the weekly quizzes are a big strength of the course, because they allowed students to solidify their understanding of all the information presented that week before moving on to new material. I've talked to people who took the course in previous semesters, in which the only grades came from big exams, and it seems that the manner in which the course was taught this semester is much more effective. I think that one weakness is that having only one exam, the final exam, does put a lot of pressure on that one exam, and it would thus be useful to receive more information about the format of the exam leading up to it and to have a practice exam. The exam this semester seemed to have a massively greater focus on anatomy, both of knowing the exact anatomical locations of brain structures and on anatomical labeling, than was conveyed during the semester. While the quizzes occasionally had a labeling question, anatomy was generally not greatly emphasized.

This course is extremely difficult. I think that it could be improved by incorporating more assignments during the semester in order to assess understanding in preparation for the course. Another alternative could be teaching less material over the course of the one semester so that digestion of all of the material is more feasible.
Although this was the first semester the quizzes were used instead of exams, I feel like they would've been more effective if they were somehow closed-note or taken in class.

We learn a lot of very interesting information during this course. The weekly quizes were time-consuming and did not prepare us adequately for the final exam. We had no real practice of anatomy or what was expected.

There was so much material to learn! It was actually so insane how much there was... I thought the lectures were very interesting, but it was hard to keep up. I just thought that we were expected to know a lot of details that were difficult to understand. The quizzes were okay for me to help learn the material, but the TFs took off so many little points!! I also thought that it was very stressful to have one big final exam at the end, without having had any other exams. I didn't really know what to expect going into it, and I wasn't sure how to study since there is so much material. I would say that maybe having 3 non-cumulative exams would have made me feel less stressed, and would have helped me learn the material better instead of having open-notes quizzes, which didn't help me learn the material that well, and having one huge exam at the end, which I crammed for. Also, the professor talked so much about stress and the importance of sleep in the last few weeks, but I'm sure the majority of students in the class were very stressed (i was) and suffered from lack of sleep (i did) going into the final, which is not good!!! Scared to look at my grade in this class :(

I think that some sort of work outside of the weekly quizzes would be helpful. I listened to the lectures and completed the quizzes, but found studying for the final extremely difficult: I had not made the connections between lectures throughout the semester. If we had monthly quizzes on certain functions or brain regions, I think I would have been able to learn the material better.

The weekly quizzes on canvas were really helpful in reducing stress throughout the semester and they forced you to analyze what you had learned the previous week. The final exam was extremely challenging because there was SO much information you had to know and we didn't really have any idea of the type of questions we would be asked because there was no practice exam or midterms to practice on.
The course overall was great. However, as a grad student, it was hard to make time to attend any of review session.

Strengths: The weekly quiz structure was extremely useful. I also thought that Prof. McCarthy did an excellent job as a lecturer and also in making all of the material available for students.
Weaknesses: It was extremely hard. TA grading on quizzes varied which was frustrating.

Strengths: lots of interesting content

weaknesses: So many minute details that the overall content being interesting becomes irrelevant. It becomes very disheartening to continue working, because it feels like there's no correlation between work and success.

I think the weekly quizzes were a great idea and a good replacement for a midterm, but both the questions and grading for these quizzes seemed to get unfairly harder as the semester went on, and even the slightest loss of points meant a pretty significant drop in quiz average (70% of your grade). The final was also way too specific to which part of the brain does what instead of more broad understandings of topics covered in the class and was generally really challenging to study for (due to unclear expectations for it).
I think it left it up to the student to force him or herself to pay attention and stay committed, and while some may like this I found that it really didn't work for me.

The course was interesting but should not be advertised as an introductory course. Aside from the fact that there was way too much information shoved into one semester, the themes seemed to lack cohesion (other than the fact that they all had something to do with the brain). For these reasons, the videotapes were my saving grace; they allowed me to slowly go over the large amounts of content in each lecture.

This course covers a lot of material about a very complicated subject: the brain. The course brings in some of the latest research and findings in neuroscience and psychology. The course could perhaps be slightly more organized. The challenge of this course is to memorize a dense amount of information.

Professor McCarthy's lectures are generally easy to follow, and the posting slides and notes was extremely helpful when studying both for the weekly quizzes and even more so for the final. The weekly quizzes are graded pretty strictly, so it's important to make sure every detail is spelled out explicitly when answering questions.

Something that this course is missing is a high-level overview of everything discussed, and the overall structure/direction of the course is a bit scattered. Different brain regions are referred to over and over again for different functions in different lectures, so by the end it's hard to keep track of what the various functions of each region are. While McCarthy does often review material from past lectures in his slides and notes, I think a more explicit list (or even review lecture) that is organized by brain region rather than functions/processes would help tie these two ideas together.

strengths = no midterms, no papers, just weekly online open-note/internet quizzes (first year the prof tried this)

failures = no midterms meant that no one was really prepared for how hard the final would be. Also, the TFs couldn't find things to take points off for on the quizzes so they started taking off points randomly and without reason. And the quizzes (each 10 points) count for 70% of our grade, so you end up losing a significant portion of your grade not because you don't understand the material but because the TFs are so nitpicky with unnecessary details in your answers.

Strengths of this course include highly detailed lectures and notes, with plenty of resources to supplement learning and studying. The material was presented in captivating ways, and lectures were concise and reasonably easy to follow.

However, this class could have been improved with a better use of the textbook. I felt that the textbook readings were long and unnecessary compared to the notes that Professor McCarthy provided.
Make the test more similar to the quizzes or vice versa, and on the test print out more clear pictures preferably in color.

This course was taught as well as it could have been. Professor McCarthy's organization and thoroughness was very impressive. The final exam was extremely detailed and stressful, but I guess that should be expected for this type of class.

The weekly quizzes eased the anxiety of having to learn so much information in so little time, so that assignment format is a strength. However, in the future, I think students would greatly benefit if this class had sections to assess the information taught at lecture and to improve upon any misunderstandings about concepts.

Lecture is engaging and fun to go to. I'm not sure how big a fan I was of the quizzes. It was good for the year, but in the long run made it hard to study for the final. Furthermore, grading on quizzes seemed very arbitrary.
Everything was great! Professor McCarthy structured it very well.
The professor was great and the quizzes were fine; yet, the final was very difficult.

A strength of this class was having the information taught solidified through a weekly three-hour quiz. The quiz was much better than having midterms because it was focused and more specific. A weakness was the sheer amount of information that was taught through the semester. This class requires a lot of memorization. This isn't really a weakness, but rather a challenge for students.

I liked the structure of the assignments, and I thought the quizzes were effective in emphasizing the important parts of the course. That being said, they did not prepare me at all for what to expect on the final exam. While they emphasized some aspects, they didn't seem to line up with what was expected of us on the final.

I think the online quizzes are a huge strength to this course instead of the midterms. The quizzes were helpful with understanding the information we needed to know and kept me reviewing my content on a weekly basis. I think the weakness is that sometimes the quizzes were ambiguous with regards to what the TAs wanted to see which caused me to lose points on questions I easily knew the answer to, but didn't say exactly what the Ta's were looking for
I thought that there wasn't enough interaction with the teacher/TAs and would have liked to have met every week to learn everything better from a smaller classroom setting.

The take-home quizzes were less stressful than midterms, but also meant it was harder to prepare for the final exam. Overall though, Professor McCarthy really facilitated learning by providing videos of lectures, lecture notes, and slides. I would say the greatest strength of this course is the many resources it provides! From the lecture videos, to Piazza, to the office hours, overall there are many ways to succeed in this class as long as you take advantage of the resources.

The strength of this course is, plainly, how fascinating and engaging it is. Prof. McCarthy is a fantastic professor and will really get you interested in neuroscience. The downside, however, is that this course is often so overwhelming and the TA's, who this time around only graded the take home quizzes, were unhelpful and gave poor feedback. The weekly quizzes were fine and gave an opportunity to do well in the course, however you generally learn nothing from doing them as you are allowed to look at notes, the textbook, the lectures etc when you're  doing them. This became a serious issue when studying for the final exam, which was quite simply the most stressful experience I've ever had to deal with in an academic sense.

I thought the weekly quizzes had the potential to be effective but in practice relied too heavily on Professor McCarthy's notes. The quizzes would have been too difficult based solely on lectures without the accompanying notes, but were slightly too easily with access to the notes. I think that this resulted in a certain pickiness in answers when the TA's graded that made the material slightly more confusing than it did clear.

Strength: Professor McCarthy was a great lecturer, and he made all the course content very accessible. The recorded lectures and review sessions were very helpful, especially in studying for the final. In addition, the weekly quizzes made sure that I was caught up with the course content.

Weakness: n/a
The new structure of the course is great! I would say the final is a little bit harder than expected as it required us to memorize far too much information!
The weekly quizzes were a great change! They really helped me learn the material and engage

The weekly open-book quiz system was great. I think it does a good job of motivating weekly review and forcing people to keep up with the program, which is good for the entire class. The overall organization of this course was stellar. Prof. McCarthy is a role model for all organized teachers. I highly appreciate his lecture slides, notes, recordings, and extra review sessions. 

The only thing that could be improved is our exposure to closed-book assignments. The fact that the final was the first closed-book assignment we had all semester was very disconcerting. I think it would be better to have both the weekly open-book quizzes and a closed-book midterm in addition to the closed-book final.

I thought that the open note quiz format made it incredibly difficult to incrementally learn the material throughout the semester. I would have preferred exams throughout the semester that forced me to learn all of the material before the final exam.

Overall, this course was interesting and well-designed, except for the glaring issue of having only open-book assignments until the final, which was cumulative. Both I and many other students found that it was nearly impossible to suddenly memorize the whole course at the end of the semester, even if we had gone to every lecture, done every reading, understood everything along the way, and gotten good grades on the weekly quizzes. In other words, the class was entirely understanding-based until the last second, when suddenly 30% of our grade was memorization-based.
Returning to the midterm format would be nice because having to do all the memorization at the end was not a good way to learn.
The weekly quizzes are helpful.
So much information is given in lecture that it becomes overwhelming and is hard to know what to study for the exam.

The course had a manageable workload, as it consisted of weekly quizzes with one final exam. However, this was ultimately the weakness of the course and I feel that a midterm exam or two would have been more productive to learning the course material, which was very memorization-intensive. An additional weakness was that none of the grading was done by the instructor, and that the level of detail required by weekly quizzes often felt haphazard, with the TAs leaving short and sometimes rude comments without noting how the mistakes could've been bettered.

The material was great - the 2 and a half lectures on the visual system were kinda boring but otherwise it was all really cool. 

But mostly just anything at all to mitigate how stressful the final was -- even a midterm (so it didn't have to be cumulative) would have helped. Also the TA grading on the online quizzes was often very nit-picky and sometimes didn't seem entirely fair.

Strengths: interestinf material, engaging professor.

Weaknesses: too much material in too much detail.
An enormous amount of information to learn in a short space of time, however very interesting.
Very interesting if you're interested in neuro, but there was way too much memorization expected for the final.
This class has an extremely large amount of information. Keeping on top of the large amounts of lecture slides is very difficult.

Excellent organization and clear communication with students 
Helpful videos and audio recording
Helpful notes

The professor submits class notes and lecture videos to the class website. The structure is good; the class notes, however, constantly have grammatical mistakes and typos, which often befuddle me as I read it.

The fact that lectures are recorded means that you can stream it at the pace you so desire. Quizzes keep you updated with understanding of the material every week. They do not take a large amount of effort as the answers are in the pages of the notes, which are also very well organized. The material was very fascinating and well motivated by Gregory McCarthy who communicated with passion and clarity the beauty of modern neuroscience.
I think that the weekly quiz format could be bolstered by having a midterm.

A strength of this course is the weekly quiz structure, which allows the workload to be spaced throughout the semester. Another strength is that the course material covers pretty much everything there is to know about the brain (though some topics are touched upon in more detail than others), allowing students to see where their specific interests lie. A weakness is that the lack of midterms means a nearly impossible amount of information that needs to be memorized for the final.
This course covers so much in not a lot of time that you feel like you are missing a lot of information. The material is really interesting though.

The strength of this course is that the lectures are very well organized and very comprehensive, making it easy both to learn specific material as well as identify broader themes in neuroscience.
The weekly quizzes that were first implemented this semester might be a weakness - I definitely appreciated not having the stress of studying for midterms and being able to break up my studying into chunks every week instead, but it did mean I had absolutely no idea how to study for the final, not having taken any exams with a similar format earlier in this course.

Fascinating class. Lots of material, and lots of rote memorization needed. But Prof. McCarthy keeps it incredibly well-structured. All lectures are recorded, and all slides and notes are posted ahead of time. I love classes that have a clear structure. 

Of course the content itself is very interesting. I'm a CS major, but I found this class changing the way I think about our behavior, habits, health and so on.
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in neuroscience. It was really interesting.
Neuroscience is fascinating, but unless you need this course for your major or you LOVE the brain, I wouldn't recommend it.
Definitely for anyone curious about neuroscience (whether interested as a major or just a casual curiosity)

I'd definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in how we think and feel. Great science credit option (if McCarthy keeps the open-book quiz structure) because you actually learn something with a very low but consistent and transparent workload during the semester. Then cram during reading period and you'll do well in the class. Even as humanities major, it felt relevant, important, and applicable to know something about the neurological basis for cognitive processes like decision-making, memory, and empathy. Plus the vision unit was incredible, and worth taking the course for on its own.
Yes, if they want a challenging science course or just to learn about the human brain!

Yes! This class is a lot of fun and goes over many of the important branches of neuroscience. It gives a good base for anyone interested in pursuing further studies. The lectures are extremely interesting (and many are applicable to daily life, like the sleep and stress lectures) you really learn a lot from the course!
Yes, simply because it is very interesting and you learn a lot, although I would advise to approach with caution because it is a lot of work and things to memorize for the final.
Yes, but I love learning about the brain and found it fascinating. You may hate the details and the memorization!
Yes, I would, if the student is keen on learning about the brain. It is a lot of information that can easily get on top of you if you let it. Allocate a lot of time to studying the material.

This course is very difficult (not a science gut) but if you are a psychology major or just interested in better understanding your own brain you absolutely should take it.  There is a lot of support by way of the TAs and weekly review sessions and the lectures are all really interesting.  You will learn a lot of valuable information and you will not do any busy work.  McCarthy is a nice, highly intelligent man who really cares about teaching.

I would recommend this course to anyone who would like to learn about the human brain; the new setup of the course with weekly quizzes makes it much more accessible to people who may not be as strong in science.

No. There are too many flaws. It NEEDS a redesign before it is ever considered recommendable by me.   I feel this course suffers because of the lack of accessibility which is funny given Professor McCarthy's claims that this is an approachable class for everyone (even the non STEM folks!) If I were to try and make an analogy for this course, it felt like you are told to run every day for a month-but only a mile, with many rests and water breaks every time you do it--manageable! Then, after the weeks of running just one mile a day, you are told to run a complete marathon nonstop with no breaks (though you should be well prepared because you've run "every day" this month! It shouldn't be a problem.) But you keel over in the second mile and then you're awake in the hospital wondering what happened and then you remember that The Human Brain final exam was one of the most unnecessarily stressful and difficult exams. I would encourage Professor McCarthy to understand that the material is DENSE. And the lack of clear communication of what is or isn't important to know is cumbersome. The brain is difficult, I get it. So much research is still ongoing and we don't know all there is. But this course often feels like you have to know every neurotransmitter, sucli and lobe in order to even get a D. It's a horrendously designed course. I'd encourage having a look at other courses like MBB300 that are able to be "Dense" without being inaccessible. The lecture slides were also way too long. Consider making a "printer friendly" copy without all of the riff raff. I swear to god the amount of changing gears slides I have printed out could make a 24x24 inch collage. This course is damaging to the human brain if anything.

Yes! This was such an interesting and engaging class-- to a degree I didn't expect possible from a large, anonymous lecture-- that truly is accessible to people from all majors. If you want to begin to learn about the awesome complexity of the human brain, understand contemporary methods of research neuroscience, evade the dullness of many introductory STEM courses, and have a greater, more subtle understanding of the human condition, then take this course!! Because of the open-note weekly quizzes 70%/ final exam 30% grading structure, if you put in a bit of work throughout the semester, you can guarantee yourself a respectable grade. So, while this isn't a gut class, it's definitely manageable, and I think everybody should consider taking it.
Take this if you're interested in neuroscience because the material is truly fascinating. Don't take this to get a science credit.

I would recommend this course because the material was very interesting, but I implore you, my fellow Yalie, to take it credit/D and switch later if you wish. The class is not that conceptually difficult; there's just way too much information that you're responsible for. Also, if you do take it, start studying for the final during Thanksgiving Break! It's THAT much information.
Yes it is a great class if you're interested in neuroscience and neuorlogical disorders and such.
Yes, it was very challenging but very interesting.
not a lot of work during the semester with weekly quizzes but final was terrible
Definitely, the material is fascinating and the professor is great. But there is A LOT of stuff to be learned.
Yes, but be sure to review piecemeal throughout the semester, which takes discipline!
I would recommend this class because it's a good mix of psychology and biology, which I really enjoyed. The accessibility of resources and course materials also made it really easy to learn.

depends. don't take this class unless you need it. If you don't need it as a credit, take it credit D because there is too much information to worry about. super interesting and everything but very hard.
its a good class to take if you're interested in neuroscience and have prior knowledge of neuroscience.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in learning more about the brain, especially to student who have some scientific background to begin with. I learned a lot, found the material to be very interesting, and thought the class was fair.

I would not recommend to anyone vaguely interested in neuroscience unless this course is a required prerequisite. It is quite difficult for a class that is not your focus /intended challenge for the semester.

I took this course as a science credit, and that was a very bad decision. Although I really enjoyed learning all this material, I am interested in psychology and neuroscience. But the weekly quizes took a long time to complete, and the final exam was very difficult. If you are looking for a science credit, do not take this course.
Only if you have to take it.. It was just a huge time commitment and not very fun to study for.
Definitely take this class!!! I would recommend doing it credit/d though if you don't plan to use it for your major because it's a ton of information to know.
I would not recommend taking this if you are not realistically interested in neuroscience. If you are, it is a fantastic introduction.

Trying to do do well in this class is like running up against a brick wall repeatedly, expecting to break through but continuously knocking yourself out.

Absolutely do NOT take this class unless you credit/d it. It is insanely, impossibly difficult, no matter how interested you are in the material.

The broader concepts are interesting but the minute details are absolutely overwhelming. The content seems to miss the forest for the trees.

While I think this course is very hard to get an A in, I would still recommend it because Professor McCarthy is very organized and the material presented is relevant (especially to psych majors of course) to anyone interested in going beyond  what high school science might teach you about the brain. Very interesting, and very necessary for psych majors, but very challenging class.

Personally. I don't. I found the lectures dry, and I found that the method of having open note weekly quizzes very unhelpful, as I found that I didn't learn much from them, and gave me a false sense of security of my knowledge of the material before the final.

This course offers a strong introduction to someone interested in the physiology behind psychology. The course is pretty low-commitment throughout the semester (2.5 hours of recorded lectures a week + a ~1hr online open book weekly quiz), although the final is pretty intense and requires a lot of studying and review during reading week.

While I don't know that this was intentional, taking this course in parallel with intro psych (PSYC110) worked extremely well, with the two courses often covering the same topics/experiments at the same time from two different but complementary perspectives.

It's a requirement for several majors. If you want to take for fun, i recommend other psych classes that go into more detail. the problem with survey courses like this one is that they cover so much material but with very little depth into each subject area.

I would recommend this course to a student interested in learning about the brain, psychology, and especially neuroscience. There is a huge amount of material to learn, but it is highly interesting if you have the time to invest yourself in it.

This class is very difficult. There is a lot of material. But, with the quizzes throughout the term being open-note and rather short, the workload wasn't particularly high in general. Studying for the final required extreme levels of memorization. It was ultimately very interesting and a fascinating class to take if you're interested in psych/neuro/cog sci.
I would absolutely recommend this class

I would recommend this class if you are interested in pursuing anything in cognitive science, in neuroscience, and/or in the biological sciences, in general. The material is dense, but it is totally worth it in the end.
Take it! You learn a lot.
Yes! Infinitely interesting course.
I would recommend this course to a student who is really passionate about learning about the brain!
Yes I would!
Yes, I really enjoyed learning the information and it was fun.

Yes! This is a challenging course, but it is super interesting, Prof. McCarthy is great and provides lectures slides and notes prior to class, so you can easily follow along as you go. If you're taking this as your science credit, godspeed. There is a lot of material, most of it very interesting, but it does require a lot of memorization.

This course is a fantastic course that will even get the most books-y humanities major interested in Neuroscience. Just note this - this is one of the most demanding, stressful courses around finals period. Despite the course content being enjoyable, it is totally overwhelming and frustrating. If you're taking this course as a Neuro or STEM major, make sure you put consistent work in (I know people tell you this often and you ignore it, but I thoroughly mean it with this course - you will NOT do well otherwise). Otherwise, this is the perfect Cr/D course.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning about the brain broadly. This is a good precursor course to more specific neuroscience classes and also has lots of lectures that philosophy or cognitive science majors might find interesting as well.

Yes, I would recommend this class. Although there was a lot of information to study for the final, I felt that we learned a lot throughout the semester. Professor McCarthy also records all his lectures, so you can go back to rewatch lectures or to review information. The weekly quizzes are not that bad either.
I would definitely recommend this class to someone! Even though you are not doing psych of neuro, this is just a great class!
Yes! The knowledge in this course can applied to a variety of fields and the professor makes it a joy to take.
Yes. The class was INCREDIBLY interesting.

I would recommend taking this course credit/D and only if strongly interested in neuroscience, as the content is fascinating but the workload is significant and uninteresting. You will learn a lot about neuroscience, but this course is quite a bit too rigorous for someone who is just looking for an introduction to the topic. If you're required to take this or choose to do so, just make sure to continuously study the material throughout the semester, as the open-book quizzes can lull you into a false sense of security that will come back to bite you come reading period.
Yeah take it.

The new format of weekly online open-note quizzes and a single final definitely decreased my stress level throughout the semester, and the difficulty of the quizzes felt very appropriate.  At the same time, the new format removed any motivation to take good notes during the semester, which led in turn to a much more stressful experience of studying for and taking the final, where I felt like I had to basically learn the entire course in a few days.  Much of this is the product of my own questionable work ethic, but I will say that since all the material was crammed in before the final, I'm not sure how much will stick.  

I think a few more tweaks to the structure of the course could really improve it.  Maybe have the anatomy/neurotransmission/more fundamental quizzes be closed note so that students actually have to study it?
Great course if you study throughout the semester.
Only if they are prepared to put in a LOT of work and focus. They need to have a real passion for the subject.

If youre really interested in learning how the brain and nervous system works, then youll probably like this class a lot! One thing to note is that the first few lectures are not at all an accurate representation of what the class is like  so dont decide whether or not to take it just from that. It is a science class about the human brain, so you will learn about a lot of pathways and anatomy and psych experiments (not humanities-esque theories about our evolution or molecular bio level cellular interactions). Theres a ton of material (i had about 100 pages of dense, single spaced notes by the end) and its fascinating! 3-hr weekly online quizzes were sometimes hard to find 3 consecutive hours for, but thats really the only work during the semester so its not bad at all, and forces you to review the material as you go. The final was definitely one of the scariest test experiences I've had at Yale (and this was my seventh semester) because there's so much material (cumulative) and the questions are highly specific, but I'd say it's still worth taking -- just maybe cr/d/fail if you're nervous. And based off the grade distribution that he emailed out just now, I'd say the class is somewhat curved even though he says it's not lol.

Take this if rote memorization of minutia is your strong suit. Overall, incredibly interesting class, but the sheer magnitude of information you have to learn is overwhelming. Study efficiently from the first lecture and you should be okay.
Yes!! It was very interesting, just beware the amount of memorization needed for the final.
Yes I would, they just need to study more than I did.

If you are interested in neuroscience, I think this class is a good fit as an introductory class. If you are more concerned with the cognitive functions associated with brain areas, take Introduction to Cognitive Science instead.

Yes, it is the best neuroscience intro class that combines comprehensive neuroanatomy, neurobiology of electrophysiological mechanisms, overview of methods, and very interesting case studies on brain syndromes.

Listen up: this will be the most honest review you will read. This course is HARD. You shouldn't take it as a gut or easy 5th credit. But if you're a doctor or scientist hoping to do anything related to the brain, you should take this course. You will learn everything you thought there is to learn about the brain and more. You will be able to pull insights from this course in your everyday life (e.g. when drinking coke or pepsi; take the course and find out what I mean). Just do yourself a favor and please review the two lectures each week before taking the weekly quiz. You will be much, much less stressed and overwhelmed before final exam period. It is definitely possible to do well in this course if you just space out the workload rather than trying to memorize everything in the two days leading up to the exam.

If you are a neuroscience or psychology major, or someone looking for a science credit that is NOT a gut, then I would recommend taking this class - although it was a lot of work, it was mostly rewarding and I learned a lot about the functioning of the brain.
